title: 107_hr5588
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2002" and includes provisions for aggravated identity theft. The "Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2002" introduces provisions for aggravated identity theft, including penalties of 2 years imprisonment for unauthorized use of another person's identification in relation to a felony, and 5 years for such actions in relation to a terrorism offense. The "Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2002" imposes a 5-year imprisonment term for transferring, possessing, or using means of identification during a felony, with consecutive sentences and no probation allowed. The term of imprisonment for a violation of this section may run concurrently with another term imposed for an additional violation of this section, as long as it follows sentencing guidelines. The term 'felony violation enumerated in subsection (c)' refers to any felony offense listed in subsection (c). The term 'felony violation enumerated in subsection (c)' refers to various felony offenses including theft, false personation, false statements, fraud, mail fraud, nationality and citizenship violations, passports and visas offenses, and violations of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. The curr_chunk lists specific sections of various acts related to obtaining customer information by false pretenses, immigration offenses, and false statements relating to social security programs. Chapter 47 of Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new item after section 1028, related to obtaining customer information by false pretenses, immigration offenses, and false statements regarding social security programs. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO EXISTING IDENTITY THEFT PROHIBITION. Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include possession of identity theft materials and increase penalties for certain offenses.
